 - There are no floor drains within the building.
 - Examples of materials stored in this location include carbon black, various liquid polymers, chemical drums and totes, and other solid materials stored in bags or reinforced cardboard drums.
 - The amount and types of oils stored in this location varies from day-to-day with an estimated storage capacity of 73,000 gallons.

Building 9: 121,866 sq/ft
 - This warehouse is also used for the storage of a wide variety of solid and liquid materials.
 - There are no floor drains.
 - The contents of this building include various liquid polymers, chemicals in drums and totes, and other materials that are stored in bags or reinforced cardboard drums.
 - The amount and types of oil varies from day-to-day with an estimated storage capacity of 37,500 gallons.

Buildings 8, and 9:
 - These buildings are used for storing oils prior to shipment.
 - None of these buildings have inside drains.
 - Occasionally products are repackaged between totes and drums using a hand pump to transfer the liquids.
 - Oil products are in closed containers (55 gallon drums or 275 gallon plastic totes) and brought to the warehouses via truck and transported to the designated storage areas via forklift.
 - As business dictates, the products are then placed on out-bound trucks for distribution in commerce.

Spill kits are located in all buildings:
 - In Building 1 near the bay doors of the loading dock.
 - In Building 8 near the bay doors at the loading dock, contains a magnetic drain cover and absorbents.
 - In Building 9 there are (2) spill kits kept within the warehouse; one near the bay door adjacent to the loading dock and one next to the bay at the loading dock.

Although Terminal Warehouse does not currently, or expect to, exceed the Reportable Quantities of the Extremely Hazardous Materials listed, future business predictions indicate the quantities could be reached or exceeded from tim

Terminal Warehouse, Inc. located at 1779 Marvo Drive, Akron, Ohio is a warehouse complex operating 5 days a week, 17 hours per day and is closed on weekends and major holidays. There are 9 buildings located with the complex.

Topography is rolling hills, with primarily residential areas in all directions surrounding the facility. The nearest residences are adjacent to the west side of the facility, next to the ball field Emergency Assembly area. There is a storm water retention pond on the northwest corner of the property that drains west/northwest into a creek that contains a minimal amount of water at low flow during the summer months. A railroad track runs along the east side of the facility outside if the fence line. At the north end of the property is a ravine ranging from 20' to 40' in depth.

Building 1: 56,440 sq/ft (L - Shaped Warehouse)
 - 14,700 sq/ft is used for staging loads and storage of non-oil products prior to shipment.

Building 2: 62,886 sq/ft
 - A portion of the warehouse is used for administrative offices with the remainder as storage for non-oil products prior to shipment.

Building 3: 9,648 sq/ft
 - This warehouse is used for the storage of hazardous materials prior to shipment. No oil products are stored in this building.

Building 4: 9,648 sq/ft
 - This warehouse is also used for the storage of hazardous materials prior to shipment and is occasionally used for the refrigerated storage.
 - The flooring in this warehouse slopes towards the center of the building to contain any potential spills.

Buildings 5-6: 19,296 sq/ft
 - Adjoining building that are also used for the storage of hazardous materials prior to shipment with no oil products stored in either.

Building 7: 38,592 sq/ft
 - This warehouse is divided into (4) sections and is used primarily for the storage of hazardous and flammable materials prior to shipment.

Building 8: 122,097 sq/ft
 - This warehouse is used for the storage of a wide variety of solid and

 - Toluene 2,6, Diisocyanate - CAS Number 91-08-7; 10,000 Reportable Quantity Release
 - Ethlenediamine - CAS Number 107-15-3; 40,000 Reportable Quantity Release

All stored in buildings 3-7 designated as hazmat buildings.

Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response
 - Terminal Warehouse takes every precaution to prevent the release of chemicals whether it is hazardous or non-hazardous. Its primary focus is on the safety and health of its employees, responders, the general public, and the protection of the environment. To avoid confusion and to prevent anxiety within the general public, Bill Hanlon, Chief Operating Officer of Terminal Warehouse isthe designated spokesmen. Should the release require the need to evacuate the surrounding area they will be responsible for informing the public of the need to evacuate, why they are being informed to evacuate, what is being done to correct the situation, and when the situation has been corrected.

 - An Emergency Coordinator and (2) alternates have been assigned to the facility and are to be contacted immediately should a release occur. The Coordinator, alternates, and all managers and supervisors have received training in response to non-hazardous emergencies and can evacuate the risk exposures. The responding coordinator will evaluate the scene to determine the risk exposures by assessing the type of chemical released and information provided on the Material Safety Data Sheet. If the release is of a non-hazardous nature, the release, confine and contain it to the immediate area to prevent further migration. If the released material is known to be hazardous or cannot be determined, all employees in the immediate vicinity are to leave the area immediately and notify the Emergency Coordinator and/or Alternate Coordinators.

 - Terminal Warehouse employees are not expected or trained to combat extremely hazardous releases.

 - Depending on the applicability and the seriousness of the situa

tion, the responding Coordinator will:
   - Notify assigned team leaders of the emergency.
   - Evacuate the immediate area of the release and/or the entire facility should it be necessary.
   - Ensure supervisors account for all their employees at the Assembly Area.
   - Initiate calls to the appropriate agencies as needed including but not limited to:
     * Fire Department
     * Spill Removal Service
     * County Hazmat
     * Ohio EPA Emergency Services
 - Ensure the erection of barricades to establish a zone of isolation that prohibits entry.
 - Stop the source of the release if it can be done so safely by up righting a drum or plugging a small hole in a drum or tote.
 - Use the proper PPE and the Buddy System no matter how small the source of the release.
 - Relay accurate information to employees through their supervisors to relieve anxiety.
 - If it can be done in a safe manner and proper training has been received the Coordinator and Emergency Response leaders will oversee the cleanup ensuring the use of proper personal protective equipment and cleanup equipment.
 - Should the release meet or exceed the reportable quantity the Emergency Coordinator will notify the appropriate agencies as required by law.
 - The Emergency Response leaders will determine and announce to all concerned when it is safe to re-enter the building or area.
